text: Hi there, quick question, is there a Julia equivalent of the unpacking operator ?

elements.text: Hi there, quick question, is there a Julia equivalent of the unpacking operator ?

text: Maybe `...` splat is what you are looking for?

elements.text: splat is what you are looking for?

text: I'm not at a computer right now: but let `f(x, y, z) = x^2 + y^2 + z^2` then `f([1, 0, 5]...)` should return 26 (just like how `f(1, 0, 5)` returns 26)

text: what do you mean when you say "unpacking operator"?

elements.text: what do you mean when you say "unpacking operator"?

text: Presumably Python "unpacking" operator <https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0448/>, which indeed is similar to Julia's splatting (although Python's is nicer in several regards)

attachments.title: PEP 448 -- Additional Unpacking Generalizations
attachments.text: The official home of the Python Programming Language

elements.text: , which indeed is similar to Julia's splatting (although Python's is nicer in several regards)

text: Yes sorry for being a bit unclear

elements.text: Yes sorry for being a bit unclear

text: Yeah I guess I saw splat somewhere

elements.text: Yeah I guess I saw splat somewhere

text: Thanks ! will give it a try :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: Thanks ! will give it a try

text:
Be aware of two "gotchas" with Julia's splatting, though:
1. First, don't splat "many" elements, say, more than about 16 or so. It can extremely slow in Julia because it stresses the compiler. (Though it depends - some places you can splat 100 elements, no problem)
2. Annoyingly, `a, b = [1, 2, 3]` does not give an error in Julia

elements.text: Be aware of two "gotchas" with Julia's splatting, though:

First, don't splat "many" elements, say, more than about 16 or so. It can extremely slow in Julia because it stresses the compiler. (Though it depends - some places you can splat 100 elements, no problem)
does not give an error in Julia

text: though there is `a, b... = [1,2,3]` in 1.6
<@UH24GRBLL> What does that do?

```julia> a,b... = [1,2,3] 
3-element Vector{Int64}:
 1                      
 2                      
 3                      
                        
julia> a                
1                       
                        
julia> b                
2-element Vector{Int64}:
 2                      
 3                      ```

elements.text:
julia> a,b... = [1,2,3] 
3-element Vector{Int64}:
 1                      
 2                      
 3                      
                        
julia> a                
1                       
                        
julia> b                
2-element Vector{Int64}:
 2                      
 3

text: Whats the difference between with the splat and without the splat in 1.6? (I'm not on 1.6 yet :sweat:)

elements.text: Whats the difference between with the splat and without the splat in 1.6? (I'm not on 1.6 yet

text: `...` is splatting (iterating over a collection to unpack it) as well as slurping (gathering elements into a collection)

elements.text: is splatting (iterating over a collection to unpack it) as well as slurping (gathering elements into a collection)

text: without `...`, `b` would just be `2` and the rest of the vector is discarded

elements.text: and the rest of the vector is discarded

text:
```julia> a,b = [1,2,3]    
3-element Vector{Int64}:
 1                      
 2                      
 3                      
                        
julia> a                
1                       
                        
julia> b                
2                       ```

elements.text:
julia> a,b = [1,2,3]    
3-element Vector{Int64}:
 1                      
 2                      
 3                      
                        
julia> a                
1                       
                        
julia> b                
2

text: Ah ok thank you
Another point, can you splat another data structure than an array ? I.e. a dict ?

elements.text: Another point, can you splat another data structure than an array ? I.e. a dict ?

text:
Sure:
```julia> d = Dict(1 => 2, 3 => 4)
Dict{Int64, Int64} with 2 entries:
  3 => 4
  1 => 2

julia> [d...]
2-element Vector{Pair{Int64, Int64}}:
 3 => 4
 1 => 2```

elements.text:
julia> d = Dict(1 => 2, 3 => 4)
Dict{Int64, Int64} with 2 entries:
  3 => 4
  1 => 2

julia> [d...]
2-element Vector{Pair{Int64, Int64}}:
 3 => 4
 1 => 2

text: OK great thanks
(splatting just calls `iterate` , so you can splat anything that is iterable, which is nearly everything in Julia, including numbers)

elements.text: , so you can splat anything that is iterable, which is nearly everything in Julia, including numbers)

text: if they are considered literals right ?

elements.text: if they are considered literals right ?

text: being literal or not has nothing to do with being splattable

elements.text: being literal or not has nothing to do with being splattable

text: being a string does
Really? :thinking_face:  how?
it's iterability (i.e. being able to iterate over the object by calling `iterate`) that determines whether you can splat or not

) that determines whether you can splat or not

 'e': ASCII/Unicode U+0065 (category Ll: Letter, lowercase)
 'l': ASCII/Unicode U+006C (category Ll: Letter, lowercase)
 'l': ASCII/Unicode U+006C (category Ll: Letter, lowercase)
 'o': ASCII/Unicode U+006F (category Ll: Letter, lowercase)```

text: not exactly
Mosè is in the place :wink:
it just happens that Strings are also iterable - that doesn't make them lists

text: Generator expressions (e.g. `(sin(x) for x in 1:10)` are also iterable, but they're not lists

elements.text: are also iterable, but they're not lists
